data.title: embarrassed
data.meta_description: EMBARRASSED meaning: 1. feeling ashamed or shy:  2. having no money:  3. feeling ashamed or shy: . Learn more.
data.text:
adjective

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ɪmˈber.əst/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ɪmˈbær.əst/

embarrassed about She felt embarrassed about undressing in front of the doctor.

[ + to infinitive ] I was too embarrassed to admit that I was scared.

Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples

ashamedHe was ashamed that he had been caught stealing.

embarrassedI was too embarrassed to admit I was wrong.

abashedShe looked at the floor, abashed.

shamefacedHe stood shamefaced at the door, looking at the vase he had just knocked to the ground.

sheepishShe startled, then gave him a sheepish smile as she picked up her dropped papers.

See more results »

financially embarrassed mainly UK humorous

See more

More examplesFewer examples

She seemed faintly embarrassed to see us there.

You have no idea how embarrassed I was.

He was so embarrassed - his face went brick-red .

She looked a bit embarrassed by all the praise.

I was too embarrassed to admit that I'd forgotten.

(Definition of embarrassed from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of embarrassed

embarrassed

When we are flushed with pleasure or embarrassed, we get pink in the cheek.

You can tell that cop is only embarrassed because she was caught on tape.

I'm still the same person, but the grown man is not embarrassed about anything that has happened to him in life.

Teachers were embarrassed that they didn't know much about students' backgrounds or language.

Interview financially successful people in your life, and do not be embarrassed to ask questions that you may think make you look stupid.

He's hurt, embarrassed and it is affecting his schooling.

Many of us are too embarrassed or uncomfortable.

When asked if there is anything they could have done differently to keep her out of another man's arms, they respond with embarrassed indignation.

Although she was initially embarrassed, she found a silver lining in her experience.

He should be embarrassed to have even tried.

Embarrassed, the nerd swallows his pride and returns back to his original friends, hat in hand.

It also keeps an embarrassed distance from the enthusiasts who treasure such relics.

You're getting embarrassed on the court, he says.

They do not post anything online they would be embarrassed to show to a parent, explain to a child, or have an employer find.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
